abstract:
This method is used to estimate the percentage of woody cover in a riparian area. The estimation is taken at ten randomly selected plots, five on each bank, within a 10m x 10m plot starting at bankfull level. The estimates are made for ground story (woody shrubs), understory (woody shrubs), and canopy cover (big trees + small trees). These estimates are then added together to get a site-wide estimate, which ranges from 0-300.

The necessity of this method lies in the importance of understanding the woody cover in riparian areas as it provides various ecological functions such as bank stabilization, nutrient cycling, and habitat for wildlife. The method follows the CHaMP - Riparian Structure Method, which is based on the Peck et al. (2001) methods used by the Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP). This standardized approach ensures consistency in data collection and analysis across different sites and over time.

The method solves any issues raised regarding inconsistent or subjective estimation of woody cover by providing a clear, objective way to quantify the percentage of woody cover in a riparian area. It also enables comparison of results between different sites and over time, contributing to effective monitoring and management of riparian ecosystems.

Three distinct types of woody cover are assessed: groundstory (woody shrubs), understory (woody shrubs), and canopy cover (big trees + small trees). Estimations for each of these categories are calculated independently, and subsequently combined by summing the results together. Site-wide estimates are derived by averaging the values from all ten plots.

The CHaMP - Riparian Structure Method adheres to the procedures outlined in Peck et al. (2001) and is consistent with the methods used by the Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP).
